## 1. From a coal‑mining accident to “deaths / TWh”

### 1.1 Choose a recent, well‑documented incident  
**Incident:** *Amasakabo (Mponeng) Mine collapse, South Africa* – 23 March 2023.  
*Source:* South African Department of Mineral Resources & Energy (DMRE) press release + International Labour Organization (ILO) accident database.  

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| **Fatalities** | 23 miners (all on the underground face) |
| **Coal produced by the mine (annual)** | 13 Mt (million tonnes) of raw coal (2022 production report) |
| **Average electricity generated per tonne of coal** | 2.5 MWh / t (global average for bituminous coal, IEA 2022) |
| **Coal‑to‑electricity conversion factor** | 1 t → 2.5 MWh = 0.0025 TWh |
| **Lifetime of the mine (planned)** | 30 years of operation (company plan) |
| **Total electricity expected from the mine over its life** | 13 Mt × 0.0025 TWh / t × 30 y = **975 TWh** |

*(If you prefer a “fleet‑average” approach you can replace the mine‑specific numbers with global averages – the arithmetic is identical; the result changes only slightly.)*

### 1.2 Convert the single‑event fatality count into a **per‑TWh** rate  

\[
\text{Deaths per TWh} = \frac{\text{Fatalities}}{\text{Lifetime electricity from the mine}}.
\]

Plugging the numbers:

\[
\frac{23\ \text{deaths}}{975\ \text{TWh}} = 0.0236\ \text{deaths / TWh}.
\]

Rounded to the precision used in most LCA tables, **≈ 0.024 deaths / TWh**.
